Operators

Emojicode defines a set of operators.

Binary operators perform an operation on two values. For example, â• is an operator that is defined for the ğŸ”¢ type and adds up two values:

23 â• 11

operator-expression âŸ¶ expression binary-operator expression

Grouping

Consider the following example:

3 â• 2 âœ–ï¸ 2

Anybody with a reasonable understanding of maths will rightly expect the result to be 7 because 2 âœ–ï¸ 2 will be evaluated first.

However, what if we wanted 3 â• 2 to be evaluated first and add 2 to the result of that? Thisis what grouping is for.

Grouping allows you specify that the result of an operation is to be evaluated without regard to any operators before or after it.

group âŸ¶ ğŸ¤œ expression ğŸ¤›

To achieve what we want, we can rewrite our code to

ğŸ¤œ 3 â• 2 ğŸ¤› âœ–ï¸ 2

and the result will be 10.

Operator Precedence

We have seen before that Emojicode knows that it must evaluate the âœ–ï¸ operation before the â• operation. This knowledge is called operator precedence.

In order to have well-defined code, there is a clearly defined order in which operators are evaluated, which is as follows. Operators at top at evaluated first.

  • ğŸš®, â—, âœ–ï¸
  • â–, â•
  • ğŸ‘ˆ, ğŸ‘‰
  • â—€ï¸, â–¶ï¸, â—€ï¸ ğŸ™Œ, â–¶ï¸ ğŸ™Œ
  • ğŸ™Œ, ğŸ˜œ
  • â­•ï¸
  • âŒ
  • ğŸ’¢
  • ğŸ¤
  • ğŸ‘

Defining Operations for custom types

You can also define operators for custom types. An operator can be defined similar to a method. This is an example from the s packageâ€™s ğŸ“‡ type:

â• b ğŸ“‡ â¡ï¸ ğŸ“‡ ğŸ‡
  count â• ğŸ”bâ—ï¸ â¡ï¸ new_count
  ğŸ’­ ...
ğŸ‰

The difference to a normal method declaration is simply that instead of an mood (â—ï¸ or â“) an operator appears. Furthermore, no name is specified.

Identity Check

ğŸ˜œ can be used to determine whether two objects references point to the same object in memory.

This isnâ€™t an equality check: Two objects might represents the same value but they are still two different object not sharing the same memory location. To determine equality use ğŸ˜› if available.

ğŸ˜œ returns true if the result of both expression are references to the same memory location.
